An $p_u$ upper TR -- lower coronal dip occurs where the magnitudes of the $p_{u,l}$ distributions diverge. Note, such could be reminiscent of the expected upper TR peak in current dissipation per particle \citep{Hansteenetal2010ApJ718,BingertPeter2011AA}, or the previously highlighted EM to underlying magnetic field strength dependence \citep{Warrenetal2012ApJ}.

However, discussions to such are deferred to the proceeding section. Diverging $p_{u,l}$ temperature distributions, in the vicinity of the TR -- coronal interface, are of interest (Figure~\ref{fig:PLI_SF_VsLogT}), based on their occurrence at the heights to which large scale open field structures are considered to originate, e.g., cooler atmospheric layers \citep{Cranmer2012SSRv}. Locations where our derived power-law indices hint to a possible self-similar generation with closed field coronal regions.


\subsection{Coronal Heating}\label{sec:Res_CorHeat}






Recall, a $p_u$ upper TR -- lower coronal dip (i.e., 5.8\,$\lesssim$\,$\log T$\,$\lesssim$\,6.3) was highlighted in $\S$~\ref{sec:RadVsMag_BrokePLaw}, that hereafter is referred to as $\log T_w$\,$\in$\,$(5.9,6.3)$. Note, $\log T_w$ correlates with TR upturns of our $a$ results (Figure~\ref{fig:PLI_SF_VsLogT}), and feature dependent derived power-law indices (Figure~\ref{fig:PLIVsLogT}). We hypothesize, as Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG} favors, across the bulk of the solar atmospheric temperature space the efficiency of magnetic energy redistribution approximately linearly scales; assumptions that are supported by the following. Linear correlations of temperature to EM distributions (e.g., \citealt{Warrenetal2012ApJ,DelZannaetal2015AA}), and pressure and loop length (e.g., \citealt{Rosneretal1978ApJ,KanoTsuneta1995ApJ}) have been previously established, while evidence for significant $\log T$\,$\approx$\,6.0 -- 6.5 unresolved emission exists (e.g., \citealt{DelZannaMason2003AA,ViallKlimchuk2012ApJ}). Thereby, it's necessary here to explain the ``obscured" $\log T_w$ radiative observations in our magnetic coupling descriptions.
















Consider a simplified plane parallel solar atmosphere segmented into cool ($\log T$\,$<$\,5.9), warm ($\log T_w$), and hot ($\log T$\,$>$6.3) layers (Figure~\ref{fig:CorHeat_Model}), each of which experiences local heating via the freely available magnetic energy (i.e., $H_{cool}$, $H_{warm}$, and $H_{hot}$, respectively; Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG}). Cool atmospheric heating, ``chromospheric evaporation" $E_{cool}$ (e.g., \citealt{Fisheretal1985ApJ,CraigMcClymont1986ApJ,Hansteenetal2010ApJ718}), would contribute to warm enhanced plasma emission.

Additionally, under the standard coronal heating picture (e.g., \citealt{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O}), downward conducted hot layer heat flux ($C_{hot}$) would provide a source of radiatively bright warm emission. Now, assuming for simplicity heated evaporating plasma ($E$) and conduction ($C$) processes represent a portion ($\delta$) of local layer heating, the total warm heating ($H^t_{warm}$) would be given by
Using similar arguments we arrive at the total cool and hot heating described by

However, discussions to such are deferred to the proceeding section. Linear correlations of temperature to EM distributions (e.g., \citealt{Warrenetal2012ApJ,DelZannaetal2015AA}), and pressure and loop length (e.g., \citealt{Rosneretal1978ApJ,KanoTsuneta1995ApJ}) have been previously established, while evidence for significant $\log T$\,$\approx$\,6.0 -- 6.5 unresolved emission exists (e.g., \citealt{DelZannaMason2003AA,ViallKlimchuk2012ApJ}). In other words, only warm conduction and evaporation contributes to the cool and hot regions, respectively, while local plus hot and cool energy redistribution processes contribute to the warm (Figure~\ref{fig:CorHeat_Model}). Here it is pointed out, we find support to these general arguments by again noting that numerous works have favored the presence of unresolved emission, particularly, correlating with our proposed $\log T_w$ space (e.g., \citealt{DelZannaMason2003AA,ViallKlimchuk2012ApJ,DelZannaetal2015AA,Warrenetal2012ApJ}). To that effect, we speculate an enhanced volume of warm heated plasma, relative to our other layers, leads to an $\log T_w$ magnetic energy redistribution efficiency dip. We emphasize, the $p$ versus $\log T$ efficiency dip as presented here would be expected to manifest as diffuse ``unorganized" emission. Below, we expound further upon such arguments.





In terms of the predominantly closed field corona, various scales of closed magnetic flux tubes exist, rooted in the network or intranetwork lanes (Figure~\ref{fig:CorHeat_Model}), and extending to various heights ($z$) from the solar photosphere  (e.g., \citealt{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O,Orangeetal2010AAS,Orangeetal2011AAS,Tan2014ApJ}). The classical one-dimension steady state loop energy equation (e.g., \citealt{Rosneretal1978ApJ,CraigMcClymont1986ApJ}) can be written in the following conservative form

Therefore, arriving at three solutions, ``classes," that should dominate observational signatures in light of our proposed model, i.e., hot local, warm local plus chromospheric evaporation, and cool conductive back heating, for decreasing $z$, respectively. These solutions offer further supportive to our previous speculations of the source of the $\log T_w$ magnetic energy redistribution dip. We also emphasize, these results align with the proposed three classes of loop solutions presented by \citet{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O}, i.e.,
\begin{enumerate}
\item[1.] Radiation dominated, where $H$ is large and $d T/dz$ is small,
\item[2.] Classical, where both $H$ and $d T/dz$ are intermediate, and
\item[3.] Conduction dominated, where $H$ is small and $d T/dz$ is large,
\end{enumerate}
respectively. 
Here we wish to point out, it is recognized no discussions were presented in relation to the driver of our hypothesized local heating ($H$), nor temporal variability, and as such we briefly discuss these below.

Note, the Sun's atmospheric is not hydrostatic \citep{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O}, nor does the corona's mass decrease over time \citep{Hansteenetal2010ApJ718,Guerreiro2013ApJ}. In that regards, we would expect time-dependent heating processes, such as postulated here, would lead to near continuous plasma heating/cooling and mass redistribution \citep{Hansteenetal2010ApJ718}, e.g., plasma heating driven by field line stress build up and dissipation (e.g., \citealt{Klimchuk2006SoPh}) from photospheric convective motions and magnetic field recycling \citep{Berger1997PhDT,Bergeretal1997SPD}.

Recognizing the presence of knee and ankle structures, and energetic scatter about (mainly above) strict $p_u(\log T)$ descriptions (Figure~\ref{fig:FvsPhi_2Fits}), we would expect additional plasma heating beyond that provided by footpoint motions. For example, the dominant heating mechanism married to a diffuse background component as proposed in recent works \citep{UritskyDavila2014ApJ,Tan2014ApJ}, and/or plasma heating via magnetohydrodynamic wave dissipation (e.g., \citealt{HollwegYang1988JGR,PoedtsGroof2004ESASP}).

Additionally the role of radiative losses in our model discussions have been avoided.

Note, radiative loss energy depletion scales as the density squared (Equation~\ref{Eqn:SimplEngCons}), while it is widely known $n_e$ decreases for increasing $z$. Shorter cooler loops of our proposed model (Figure~\ref{fig:CorHeat_Model}), characterized by apex densities  greater than their hot counterparts \citep{Hansteenetal2014Sci}, would experience more efficient energy depletion via radiative losses, compared to thermal conduction dominated losses of the longer, hotter, loops \citep{Spadaroetal2006ApJ,Hansteenetal2010ApJ718,Guerreiro2013ApJ}. Thus, in relation to our model, local heating presumably occurs self-consistently across all layers, where progressively cooler atmospheric layers experience more efficient radiative cooling \citep{Hansteenetal2014Sci}.








\section{Discussion}\label{sec:MEC_Dis}




Using the common practice of a strict linear expression for radiative to magnetic energy coupling (Equation~\ref{eqn:PevFit}), energetic descriptions (i.e., $p$) of CHs, QS, ARs, ARCs, and FD features revealed consistencies to previous literature (i.e., $\S$~\ref{sec:RadVsMag_LinearPLaw}). However, given our broad electromagnetic spectrum coverage, observational consistencies were confined to similarly studied portions of the spectrum, i.e., soft X-ray. Our magnetic energy coupling study, including both predominantly large scale open and closed magnetic fields, indicated a single atmospheric heating description, particularly for coronal temperature regimes (i.e., $\log T$\,$\ge$\,6.0) was more appropriately described via a broken power-law (i.e., $\S$~\ref{sec:RadVsMag_BrokePLaw}). Results which favor notions for differing central engines of the open and closed field corona (e.g., \citealt{Klimchuk2014arXiv}).

However, at progressively cooler atmospheric layers, i.e., $\log T$\,$\le$\,6.0, evidence for differing open versus closed field central engines became increasingly blurred (e.g., $\S$~\ref{sec:RadVsMag_BrokePLaw} and Figure~\ref{fig:FvsPhi_2Fits}).

Specifically, results indicated

chromospheric to upper TR regimes of CHs favored self-similar plasma heating to QS, FD, and a to a lesser degree ARs (Figures~\ref{fig:FvsPhi} and \ref{fig:PLIVsLogT}).


The QS energetic distributions, for $\log T$\,$\ge$\,6.0, overlap with that of CHs found here (Figure~\ref{fig:FvsPhi}), could point to presence of self-similar processes leading to open-field structures, i.e., interchange reconnection events leading to jets (e.g., \citealt{YokoyamaShibata1995Natur}). Speculations consistent with the finds of \cite{Orangeetal2015ApJ}, whose QS evidence of such energy redistribution events were characterized by differing visibly bright radiative signatures, compared to other gross features, due to the QS large scale magnetic field geometry. 
Note, due to the general QS geometry, some jets therein are characterized as loop brightenings resultant from opposing horizontal flows (e.g., \citealt{Shibataetal1994xspy,YokoyamaShibata1996PASJ}). Therefore we hypothesize physical processes attributed to CH formation could be common in QS conditions, where large scale magnetic field geometries lead to radiative observations of more ``diffusely" heated plasma. We emphasize, such suggestions align with evidence for the ubiquitous occurrence of solar atmospheric jet phenomena (e.g., \citealt{Shimojoetal1998SoPh,ShimojoShibata2000AdSpR}).


The ARC's upper TR -- lower corona ankle of radiative to magnetic flux comparisons (i.e., Figure~\ref{fig:FvsPhi}) was speculated as an additional heating component not related to the freely available magnetic energy.

Its nearly linearly related radiative to magnetic energy distribution from lower chromospheric through upper coronal emission could be a result of

ubiquitous plasma heating across all solar atmospheric layers, i.e., runaway SOC events. Events

akin to the coupled diffuse heating component with energy dissipation from SOC-like avalanches \citep{UritskyDavila2014ApJ}.


Interestingly, our ARC ankle

correlates with the region typically considered as ``unresolved" (e.g., 6.0\,$\le$\,$\log T$\,$\le$\,6.5; \citealt{DelZannaetal2015AA}), where \cite{Warrenetal2012ApJ} indicated a switch occurs in EM distributions relation to the underlying magnetic field strength (e.g., see their Figure 9). Thus, our ARC data set is considered supportive to notions for both high and low frequency impulsive heating (e.g., \citealt{Warrenetal2012ApJ}), as well as a challenge to current coronal heating models (e.g., \citealt{BrooksWarren2015arXiv}).

However, as we have only statistically sampled these features we provide no discussions if such speculations relates to the age of the AR (e.g., see \citealt{SchmelzPathak2012ApJ}).






Though our modeled atmosphere (Figure~\ref{fig:CorHeat_Model}) represents extremely generalized descriptions of the complex coronal heating problem (e.g., \citealt{Klimchuk2006SoPh}), we emphasize its alignment with the lukewarm loop

model of \cite{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O}. Note, their model predicted the appearance of CHs in the upper TR and corona, network element width with temperature, and TR plasma downflows. Of distinct importance, our work possibly provides a key missing element to the \cite{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O} study -- the single dominant generation mechanism (i.e., Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG}). In addition, it was shown that our model inadvertently led to the three predicted loop class solutions of the \cite{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O} model.










































































\section{Summary}\label{sec:MEC_SummaryConclusion}

Observational data from all available AIA passbands and HMI LOS magnetograms at approximately 3 -- 5 day intervals during May 2010 -- July 2013 were utilized to characterize the typical radiative and magnetic fluxes, respectively, of CH, QS, AR, ARCs, and at FD scales. Note these data provided coverage of photospheric (i.e., visible) through upper coronal plasmas (i.e., soft X-ray) of the predominantly open and closed coronal magnetic field environments of the gross feature classes dominating the solar disk, independent of activity phase.

Radiative to magnetic energy coupling assessments were carried out with and without feature dependence. First, with feature dependence by using the typical approach, i.e., Equation~\ref{eqn:PevFit}. These results revealed consistencies to existing literature (e.g., \citealt{Pevtsovetal2003ApJ}) at similarly analyzed energy ranges (i.e., soft X-ray), while highlighting a possible entanglement of thermodynamic and magnetic energy contributions in such approaches (Figure~\ref{fig:PLI_SF_VsLogT}). An improved method using Equation~\ref{eqn:FvsB_BPL}, a broken power-law (Figure~\ref{fig:FvsPhi_2Fits}), was applied to our data without feature dependence. This description reasonably approximated magnetic energy redistribution across previously unexplored (to best of our knowledge) temperature regimes of the predominantly open and closed field corona. Evidence for temperature dependent magnetic energy redistribution from chromospheric through coronal regimes (i.e, Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG}), revealed in this analysis, was utilized to develop a simple theoretical coronal heating model in $\S$~\ref{sec:Res_CorHeat}.

Our work supported the expected fundamentally differing heating in regimes dominated by single polarity magnetic flux, i.e., closed versus open field heating (e.g., \citealt{Pevtsovetal2003ApJ,Klimchuk2006SoPh}). However, as such evidence was limited to coronal regimes, this work significantly elevates the role of cooler atmospheric studies (i.e., $\log T$\,$\le$\,6.0) in identifying the source and origin of CHs, and solar wind mass feeding \citep{Orangeetal2015ApJ}. Moreover, it has suggested the inferred fundamental difference of open to closed field plasma heating is possibly similar to that of jets and flares (e.g., \citealt{Shibataetal1992PASJ,WangSheely1993ApJ,Wangetal1996Sci,Shibataetal1997ASPC}).

Our observationally derived dependence of magnetic energy redistribution with temperature (Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG}) provides the first (to best of our knowledge) evidence of previously speculated notions, e.g., \citealt{Longcope1998ApJ,LongcopeKankelborg1999ApJ}. We emphasize, these results raise interesting prospects for studies detailing similar physical processes under differing plasma conditions \citep{Orangeetal2014SoPh1557O}. Our model, founded upon Equation~\ref{eqn:P=TG}, aligned well with the works of \cite{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O,Oluseyietal1999ApJ527-992O}, and provided significant provisions to the scope of these studies. Specifically, our work provided the unknown single generation mechanism missing from theirs.


Distinctly interesting to this work is

the average solar DEM is obtained irrespective of gross feature (e.g., \citealt{RaymondDolye1981ApJ,Athay1981ApJ}), as well as is appropriate for stars \citep{AntiochosNoci1986ApJ}. Note, such indicates a single mechanism as the source of plasma emission  \citep{Oluseyietal1999ApJ524-1105O}.

Irrespective of our gross feature analyses, and at full disk scales, $p(\log T)$ descriptions were reminiscent to typical solar DEMs. Straightforwardly then, our $p(\log T)$ results favor a single heating mechanism, while potentially revealing its intimate connection to DEMs (i.e., see $\S$~\ref{sec:RadVsMag_LinearPLaw} and Figure~\ref{fig:PLIVsLogT}).

Thereby, this work casts new light on the utility of narrowband observations as ad hoc tools for extrapolating solar atmospheric thermodynamic profiles; speculations with far reaching applications to the fields of solar and stellar physics.

This study has addressed SDO's objective to increase our understanding of the origin of solar activity \citep{Pesnelletal2012SoPh}. In addition, this study has indicated proxies that hold significant potential for the field of stellar physics. Mainly possible means for probing distant stellar sources in currently difficult and/or undetectable energy ranges, and techniques for extrapolating radiative to magnetic field characteristics of gross feature classes via unresolved stellar disk observations. Therefore, our work elevates SDO's extensive data archive as a tool for enhancing our understanding of stellar physics.
